Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Rihab,

Congrats on the results!

The robustness seem to be a common pro=
blem when being greedy. We noticed
that picking the agent with THE highest =
score ever was resulting on poor
median scores, but overall the evolving po=
pulation was still producing
individuals that are robust to the no-ops. On =
our latest version we added a
more robust elite selection procedure that mi=
tigates this issue.

Best regard,
Felipe

On Sun, Jun 3, 2018 at 5:06 AM, R=
ihab Gorsane rihab.gorsane@...
[neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:=


>
> [Attachment(s) <#m_2374212864787020521_TopText> from Rihab Gorsane
> =
included below]
>
>
> Hi all,
>  I am glad to share with you the results I =
got after running my
> distributed genetic implementation on Frostbite Atar=
i game.
>
> Due to the limited hardware resources I have (only available 36=
 CPU
> cores),  I fixed the population size to only 1000 individuals.
> I s=
topped the training after 100 generations because waiting to reach 1B
> fra=
mes costs a lot of time. These 100 generations proceeded about 321402808
> =
frames.
> I saved  the Highest performing model every 50 generation:
> At g=
eneration 50, the best model scored 4490 and at generation 100 the
> best m=
odel scored 5350 which is considered a very exciting result as far as
> I k=
now.
>
> There is something that is not clear to me:
> I have followed the =
paper baselines for no-op operations but I noticed
> that the agent is not =
robust at random starts ( the median at generation
> 100 was 180)
> I am wo=
ndering if anyone could clarify this for me or tell me if this
> problem is=
 also encountered in your implementation.
>
> Thank you,
> Best regards,
> =
=E1=90=A7
>
> 2018-05-30 9:46 GMT+01:00 Rihab Gorsane <rihab.gorsane@ensi-u=
ma.tn>:
>
>> Thank you Felipe,
>>
>> Best regards,
>>
>> 2018-05-30 0:19 GM=
T+01:00 Felipe Such felipe.such@... [neat] <
>> neat@yahoogroups.com>:=

>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Hi Rihab,
>>>
>>> Feel free to reach out with any questions=
, we are glad people are
>>> interested on the paper and reproducing it's r=
esults.
>>> We are using NoFrameskip-v4. We follow the same preprocessing s=
teps as
>>> other methods (Example: https://github.com/openai/base
>>> line=
s/blob/master/baselines/common/atari_wrappers.py). We use the
>>> accumulat=
ed reward (no discount factor, no clipping).
>>> You are right on the 20k f=
rames limit as it translates to 5k timesteps
>>> after the frame skips.
>>>=

>>> Best regard,
>>> Felipe
>>>
>>> On Tue, May 29, 2018 at 1:59 AM, Rihab=
 Gorsane rihab.gorsane@...
>>> [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:=

>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> Hi all,
>>>>
>>>> I've begun reproducing the DeepNeuroe=
volution paper in Pytorch. I've
>>>> considered only the Atari case study t=
o test my algorithm on.
>>>> In the paper, it's mentioned that "During trai=
ning, each agent is
>>>> evaluated on a full episode (capped at 20k frames)=
, which can include
>>>> multiple lives and fitness is the final episode re=
ward". Thus I think that
>>>> I need to track the number of frames each age=
nt is proceeding and limit its
>>>> evaluation at 20k frames ( 5k frames fo=
r my case since I'm doing k=3D4 frame
>>>> skipping technique for some game=
s).
>>>>
>>>> I was wondering if anyone could tell me which environment Ube=
r was
>>>> wrapping ( -v0 or -v4, doing frame skipping or not) and also for=
 the
>>>> reward, are they just picking the last reward as the fitness scor=
e or
>>>> calculating the accumulated reward or doing some reward clipping.=

>>>>
>>>> Thank you,
>>>>
>>>>
>>>
>>
> 
>

      <p></p><div dir=3D"ltr">Hi Rihab,<div><br></div><div>Fe=
el free to reach out with any questions, we are glad people are interested =
on the paper and reproducing it's results.</div><div>We are using NoFra=
meskip-v4. We follow the same preprocessing steps as other methods (Example=
: <a href=3D"https://github.com/openai/baselines/blob/master/baselines/comm=
on/atari_wrappers.py" target=3D"_blank">https://github.com/openai/base<wbr>=
lines/blob/master/baselines/co<wbr>mmon/atari_wrappers.py</a>). We use the =
accumulated reward (no discount factor, no clipping).<br></div><div>You are=
 right on the 20k frames limit as it translates to 5k timesteps after the f=
rame skips.</div><div><br></div><div>Best regard,</div><div>Felipe<br></div=
></div><div><div class=3D"m_2374212864787020521m_3569974043165448771h5"><di=

      <p></p><div dir=3D"ltr"><div>Hi all, <br></div><div><br></div><div>I=
've begun reproducing the DeepNeuroevolution paper in Pytorch. I've=
 considered only the Atari case study to test my algorithm on.=C2=A0</div><=
div>In the paper, it's mentioned that "During training, each agent=
 is evaluated on a full episode (capped at 20k frames), which can include m=
ultiple lives and fitness is the final episode reward". Thus I think t=
hat I need to track the number of frames each agent is proceeding and limit=
 its evaluation at 20k frames ( 5k frames for my case since I'm doing k=
=3D4 frame skipping technique for some games). <br></div><div><br></div><di=
v>I was wondering if anyone could tell me which environment Uber was wrappi=
